statement.tex:
%text Assume that the chances of a patient having a heart attack is 40\%. Assuming that a meditation and yoga course reduces the risk of a heart attack by 30\% and prescription of certain drugs reduces its chances by 25\%. At a time, a patient can choose any of the two options with equal probabilities. It is given that after going through one of the two options, a patient selected at random suffers a heart attack.
Find the probability that the patient followed a course of meditation and yoga. Interpret the result and state which of the above methods is beneficial for the patient. %

\\ \textbf{Right or wrong?} %text
For a patient who takes either yoga or the drug, the probability of having a heart attack is as follows. %

\\ %text Given the following events % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Takes Yoga} & \text{Takes Drug} & \text{Has heart-attack} \\ \hline Y & D & H \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text what probabilities did we find in Step 1? And what do we need to find now? %
\\ %text Are the calculations below correct? And have the right conclusions been drawn? %

reason.tex:
%text For a patient who takes \underline{\text{neither}} of yoga or the drug, the probability of having a heart attack is 40\%.
But if he takes one of the two, the risk reduces. % \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|} \hline \text{If }\ldots & \text{Reduction} & \text{Probability} \\ \hline \text{Yoga} & 30\% & (1-0.3)\cdot 40\% = 0.28 \\ \hline \text{Drug} & 25\% & (1-0.25)\cdot 40\% = 0.3 \\ \hline \end{tabular}

%text In Step 1, we found the probability of a patient having a heart attack \underline{\text{later}} given that he took one of yoga or the drug \underline{\text{today}}.
These are therefore conditional probabilities. And mathematically, they are written as $P(H\vert Y)$ and $P(H\vert D)$.
What we need to find is the probability that the patient took Yoga \underline{\text{given that}} he has had a heart attack.
Once again, this is conditional probability. And it is expressed mathematically as $P(Y\vert H)$. %
